photo.description: Duke of York's Column found on Regent Street/Pall Mall at the top of the Duke of York Steps. Sorry for the dark photo. This is the man we sing about in the nursey rhyme, 'The Grand Old Duke of Work'. The Crimean War Memorial is a few seconds walk behind it, which the duke faces. Wiki: www.wikipedia.org/wiki/Duke_of_York_Column

photo.description: Things Will Never Be the Same Again 30.1 See the five years later snowy version. The statue is a work of Sir Richard Westmacott, the 123-feet-high column was designed by Benjamin Wyatt, funds for the statue were raised by stopping one day's pay from every soldier in the late Duke's army; the memorial was erected in 1883. The late Duke was the second son of George III, Commander-in-Chief of the British Army between 1795-1809 and 1811-1827, respectively. The column also involves a viewing platform on the upper part, but it was closed after a series of suicides at the early 20th century.
photo.tags: london statue statuary themall westmacott sirrichardwestmacott benjaminwyatt
photo.title: Duke of York Column

photo.description: Buildings in Victoria, London. We were here to see Wicked at the Apollo Victoria. Found another theatre here - the Victoria Palace Theatre. Currently showing Billy Elliot. It is Grade II* listed. Victoria Palace Theatre, Westminster WESTMINSTER 1900/99/10473 VICTORIA STREET 23-JUN-72 (North side) Victoria Palace Theatre (Formerly listed as: VICTORIA STREET SW1 VICTORIA PALACE VARIETY THEATRE) II* Theatre. Built 1911 by the variety magnate Alfred Butt, to the design of Frank Matcham. Builders Henry Lovatt Ltd. Extended 2000. PLAN: Comprises deep frontage block 3 bays wide and 3 bays deep. 4 storeys plus basement and concealed attic. The bay at the very centre of the block was originally 3 storeys, with lantern and lightwell above, now floored over. Entrance lobby leads through to central foyer and large auditorium to N with dress circle and gallery. Outer bays contain separate stair compartments, serving the dress circle to right (W) and gallery to left (E). Grand stair in rear bay of foyer leads down to stalls on left and up to dress circle on right. Above the foyer is a series of bars: at first floor the dress circle bar (originally the Ladies' Tea Room or Adams Room); at second the Tudor (originally 'Old English') Bar, accessed by an enclosed stair at the rear of the dress circle, and at third bar only one bay deep serving the gallery; this was extended rearwards over the roof and lantern of the Tudor Bar in 2000. A former manager's flat at attic level is now offices; this too was extended rearwards in 2000. A basement bar is now much altered. At ground floor, to the E of the main building in what was an pre-existing building, is the former 'stalls saloon' bar. In front of this is a second foyer, installed in 2000 in the former gallery queuing yard, which is interlinked with the main foyer. MATERIALS: FaÃ§ade clad in 'Penteliko' and 'Keramo' white faience produced by Gibbs & Canning; return (W) elevation faced in red brick, faience and stone. EXTERIOR: Baroque style. Symmetrical 3-bay front with broader central bay. Central entrance with original polished hardwood glazed doors with curvilinear glazing bars and bevel-edged glass. Cantilevered entrance canopy with coloured glass front bearing theatre name dates from 1927. Doors to staircases to either side. Central bay projects slightly with great niche rising through first and second floors with key bearing female bust. Now obscured by advertising, the niche has a balcony with tripartite windows with French doors to central bay and decorative iron balustrade, above which is a decorative typanum with an oval window. Open loggia with Ionic columns to third floor; flanking pilasters have cartouches to tops; pediment over. Plain frieze; parapet bears theatre name in red faience lettering. Stair windows to either side of niche on 3 levels comprise keyed oculi to ground floor, and paired square-headed windows to mezzanine and first floor. Oval windows to third floor with cherub-head keystones and swags, flanked by niched Ionic columns. Rich modillion cornice. Parapet bearing 2 over-life-size female figures, and urns to each corner. Crowning octagonal Ionic cupola in manner of Wren, bearing gilded figure of Anna Pavlova (replicated from original taken down in 1940 and lost). To right (E) is a single-storey triple-arched entrance with a balustraded parapet bearing the theatre name, formerly leading to a queuing yard for the gallery, now the entrance to the 2000 foyer extension. Symmetrical side (W) elevation of 4 storeys and 9 bays arranged 1-2-3-2-1; outer single bays slightly recessed, inner ones are divided into 3 main bays (2-3-2) by rusticated pilasters. Chanelled rusticated ground floor with central entrance and vehicle entrances to outer bays. Above, central 3 bays are recessed and faced in stone with giant order of coupled Ionic columns in antis. Paired casement windows. Modillion cornice. The pub to the left of the theatre is the Duke of York.
photo.tags: london greaterlondon england unitedkingdom greatbritain victoria westminster cityofwestminster theatre victoriapalace victoriapalacetheatre billyelliot musical gradeiilisted gradeiilistedbuilding alfredbutt frankmatcham henrylovattltd penteliko keramo gibbscanning pub publichouse dukeofyork dukeofyorkvictoria victoriast
photo.title: Billy Elliot - Victoria Palace - Victoria, London - Duke of York pub

Duke of York's Column, Waterloo Place, London, WC2, 7th November 2010

photo.description: This is the Duke of York column, a monument in London, to Prince Frederick, Duke of York, the second eldest son of King George III. I was out on a stroll on the Sunday morning when I saw the criss-cross trails. I decided to click the moment I saw an air plane intersecting a previous trail. The whole scene made me imagine the Duke slicing up the sky with his sword and watching with relish. The pigeon on his head does diminish his royalty a bit...
photo.tags: dukeofyorkcolumn column memorial war sky patterns airplane trail princefrederick regentstreet mall waterlooplace sirrichardwestmacott slices heaven blue morning canon 5dmarkii london england
photo.title: A Slice of Heaven

photo.description: The Monument to the Great Fire of London, more commonly known as The Monument is a 61-metre (202-foot) tall stone Roman doric column. It is located at the junction of Monument Street and Fish Street Hill, 61 metres from where the Great Fire of London started in 1666. It consists of a large fluted Doric column built of Portland stone topped with a gilded urn of fire, and was designed by Christopher Wren and Robert Hooke. The west side of the base of the Monument displays an emblematical sculpture (pictured here), by Caius Gabriel Cibber, in alto and bas relief, of the destruction of the City; with King Charles II, and his brother, James, the Duke of York (later James II) surrounded by Liberty, Architecture, and Science, giving directions for its restoration. Its 61-metre height marks the monument's distance to the site of Thomas Farynor, the king's baker's shop in Pudding Lane, where the fire began. At the time of construction (between 1671 and 1677) it was the tallest freestanding stone column in the world. It is possible to reach the top of the monument by climbing up the narrow winding staircase of 311 steps. A cage was added in the mid-19th century at the top of the Monument to prevent people jumping off, after six people had committed suicide between 1788 and 1842. Three sides of the base of the monument carry inscriptions in Latin. The one on the south side describes actions taken by Charles II following the fire. The one on the east describes how the monument was started and brought to perfection, and under which mayors. The one on the north describes how the fire started, how much damage it caused, and how the fire was extinguished. In 1681 the words "but Popish frenzy, which wrought such horrors, is not yet quenched" were added to the end of the inscription. (The west side is described above.) The inscription on the east generally blames Roman Catholics for the fire, and this prompted Alexander Pope to say, of the area that it is where, Where Londonâ€™s column, pointing at the skies, Like a tall bully, lifts the head and lies." -- Moral Essays. Epistle iii. Line 339 (1733-1734). The words were eventually chiselled out in 1831. Wren and Hooke built the Monument to double as a scientific instrument. It has a central shaft meant for use as a zenith telescope and for use in gravity and pendulum experiments that connects to an underground laboratory for observers to work (accessible from the present-day ticket booth). A hinged lid in the urn covers the opening to the shaft. The steps in the shaft of the tower are all apparently exactly 6 inches high, allowing them to be used for accurate barometric pressure studies.
photo.tags: uk unitedkingdom britain greatbritain londonist europe thecity monument themonument monumenttothegreatfireoflondon greatfire fireoflondon memorial london england
photo.title: UK - London - The City: The Monument - west base

Its 61-metre height marks the monument's distance to the site of Thomas Farynor, the king's baker's shop in Pudding Lane, where the fire began. photo.description: The equestrian statue in the middle of Waterloo Place is not the expected statue of King Edward VII, but one Baron Napier of Magdala. General Napier was successful in defeating the Abyssinian Emperor at the battle of Magdala in 1868, after the Emperor took Missionary hostages. The statue was erected in 1891 and removed in 1920 and placed in Queens Gate.
photo.tags: pedestrians cannon row metropolitan london uk waterlooplace carltonhouseterrace dukeofyorkcolumn canonrow germanembassy 1stbaronnapierofmagdala cannonrow
photo.title: Waterloo Place

photo.description: From Wikipedia - The Monument to the Great Fire of London, more commonly known as The Monument, is a 202 ft (61.57 metre) tall stone Roman Doric column in the City of London, England, near the northern end of London Bridge. It stands at the junction of Monument Street and Fish Street Hill, 202 ft (61.57 metres) from where the Great Fire of London started in 1666. Another monument, the Golden Boy of Pye Corner marks the point near Smithfield where the fire stopped. Monument tube station is named after the monument. Constructed between 1671 and 1677, it is the tallest isolated stone column in the world. The Monument consists of a fluted Doric column built of Portland stone topped with a gilded urn of fire, and was designed by Christopher Wren and Robert Hooke. Its 202 foot (61.57 metre) height marks its distance from the site in Pudding Lane of the shop of Thomas Farynor, the king's baker, where the fire began. The top of the Monument is reached by a narrow winding staircase of 311 steps. A cage was added in the mid-19th century at the top of the Monument to prevent people jumping off, after six people had committed suicide between 1788 and 1842. Three sides of the base carry inscriptions in Latin. The one on the south side describes actions taken by Charles II following the fire. The one on the east describes how the Monument was started and brought to perfection, and under which mayors. The one on the north describes how the fire started, how much damage it caused, and how the fire was extinguished. In 1681 the words "but Popish frenzy, which wrought such horrors, is not yet quenched" were added to the end of the inscription. The inscription on the east generally blames Roman Catholics for the fire, and this prompted Alexander Pope to say of the area that it is: Where Londonâ€™s column, pointing at the skies, Like a tall bully, lifts the head and lies." -- Moral Essays. Epistle iii. Line 339 (1733-1734). The words were chiselled out in 1831. The west side of the base displays a sculpture, by Caius Gabriel Cibber, in alto and bas relief, of the destruction of the City; with King Charles II, and his brother, James, the Duke of York (later James II) surrounded by Liberty, Architecture, and Science, giving directions for its restoration. The nearest London Underground station is Monument.
photo.tags: england london patrickinlondon bigbustour londonbridge memorial monument greatfireoflondon monumentstreet fishstreethill
photo.title: Monument to the Great Fire of London

photo.description: Buildings in Victoria, London. We were here to see Wicked at the Apollo Victoria. Found another theatre here - the Victoria Palace Theatre. Currently showing Billy Elliot. It is Grade II* listed. Victoria Palace Theatre, Westminster WESTMINSTER 1900/99/10473 VICTORIA STREET 23-JUN-72 (North side) Victoria Palace Theatre (Formerly listed as: VICTORIA STREET SW1 VICTORIA PALACE VARIETY THEATRE) II* Theatre. Built 1911 by the variety magnate Alfred Butt, to the design of Frank Matcham. Builders Henry Lovatt Ltd. Extended 2000. PLAN: Comprises deep frontage block 3 bays wide and 3 bays deep. 4 storeys plus basement and concealed attic. The bay at the very centre of the block was originally 3 storeys, with lantern and lightwell above, now floored over. Entrance lobby leads through to central foyer and large auditorium to N with dress circle and gallery. Outer bays contain separate stair compartments, serving the dress circle to right (W) and gallery to left (E). Grand stair in rear bay of foyer leads down to stalls on left and up to dress circle on right. Above the foyer is a series of bars: at first floor the dress circle bar (originally the Ladies' Tea Room or Adams Room); at second the Tudor (originally 'Old English') Bar, accessed by an enclosed stair at the rear of the dress circle, and at third bar only one bay deep serving the gallery; this was extended rearwards over the roof and lantern of the Tudor Bar in 2000. A former manager's flat at attic level is now offices; this too was extended rearwards in 2000. A basement bar is now much altered. At ground floor, to the E of the main building in what was an pre-existing building, is the former 'stalls saloon' bar. In front of this is a second foyer, installed in 2000 in the former gallery queuing yard, which is interlinked with the main foyer. MATERIALS: FaÃ§ade clad in 'Penteliko' and 'Keramo' white faience produced by Gibbs & Canning; return (W) elevation faced in red brick, faience and stone. EXTERIOR: Baroque style. Symmetrical 3-bay front with broader central bay. Central entrance with original polished hardwood glazed doors with curvilinear glazing bars and bevel-edged glass. Cantilevered entrance canopy with coloured glass front bearing theatre name dates from 1927. Doors to staircases to either side. Central bay projects slightly with great niche rising through first and second floors with key bearing female bust. Now obscured by advertising, the niche has a balcony with tripartite windows with French doors to central bay and decorative iron balustrade, above which is a decorative typanum with an oval window. Open loggia with Ionic columns to third floor; flanking pilasters have cartouches to tops; pediment over. Plain frieze; parapet bears theatre name in red faience lettering. Stair windows to either side of niche on 3 levels comprise keyed oculi to ground floor, and paired square-headed windows to mezzanine and first floor. Oval windows to third floor with cherub-head keystones and swags, flanked by niched Ionic columns. Rich modillion cornice. Parapet bearing 2 over-life-size female figures, and urns to each corner. Crowning octagonal Ionic cupola in manner of Wren, bearing gilded figure of Anna Pavlova (replicated from original taken down in 1940 and lost). To right (E) is a single-storey triple-arched entrance with a balustraded parapet bearing the theatre name, formerly leading to a queuing yard for the gallery, now the entrance to the 2000 foyer extension. Symmetrical side (W) elevation of 4 storeys and 9 bays arranged 1-2-3-2-1; outer single bays slightly recessed, inner ones are divided into 3 main bays (2-3-2) by rusticated pilasters. Chanelled rusticated ground floor with central entrance and vehicle entrances to outer bays. Above, central 3 bays are recessed and faced in stone with giant order of coupled Ionic columns in antis. Paired casement windows. Modillion cornice. The pub to the left of the theatre is the Duke of York.
photo.tags: london greaterlondon england unitedkingdom greatbritain victoria westminster cityofwestminster theatre victoriapalace victoriapalacetheatre billyelliot musical gradeiilisted gradeiilistedbuilding alfredbutt frankmatcham henrylovattltd penteliko keramo gibbscanning pub publichouse dukeofyork dukeofyorkvictoria victoriast
photo.title: Billy Elliot - Victoria Palace - Victoria, London

photo.description: Buildings in Victoria, London. We were here to see Wicked at the Apollo Victoria. Found another theatre here - the Victoria Palace Theatre. Currently showing Billy Elliot. It is Grade II* listed. Victoria Palace Theatre, Westminster WESTMINSTER 1900/99/10473 VICTORIA STREET 23-JUN-72 (North side) Victoria Palace Theatre (Formerly listed as: VICTORIA STREET SW1 VICTORIA PALACE VARIETY THEATRE) II* Theatre. Built 1911 by the variety magnate Alfred Butt, to the design of Frank Matcham. Builders Henry Lovatt Ltd. Extended 2000. PLAN: Comprises deep frontage block 3 bays wide and 3 bays deep. 4 storeys plus basement and concealed attic. The bay at the very centre of the block was originally 3 storeys, with lantern and lightwell above, now floored over. Entrance lobby leads through to central foyer and large auditorium to N with dress circle and gallery. Outer bays contain separate stair compartments, serving the dress circle to right (W) and gallery to left (E). Grand stair in rear bay of foyer leads down to stalls on left and up to dress circle on right. Above the foyer is a series of bars: at first floor the dress circle bar (originally the Ladies' Tea Room or Adams Room); at second the Tudor (originally 'Old English') Bar, accessed by an enclosed stair at the rear of the dress circle, and at third bar only one bay deep serving the gallery; this was extended rearwards over the roof and lantern of the Tudor Bar in 2000. A former manager's flat at attic level is now offices; this too was extended rearwards in 2000. A basement bar is now much altered. At ground floor, to the E of the main building in what was an pre-existing building, is the former 'stalls saloon' bar. In front of this is a second foyer, installed in 2000 in the former gallery queuing yard, which is interlinked with the main foyer. MATERIALS: FaÃ§ade clad in 'Penteliko' and 'Keramo' white faience produced by Gibbs & Canning; return (W) elevation faced in red brick, faience and stone. EXTERIOR: Baroque style. Symmetrical 3-bay front with broader central bay. Central entrance with original polished hardwood glazed doors with curvilinear glazing bars and bevel-edged glass. Cantilevered entrance canopy with coloured glass front bearing theatre name dates from 1927. Doors to staircases to either side. Central bay projects slightly with great niche rising through first and second floors with key bearing female bust. Now obscured by advertising, the niche has a balcony with tripartite windows with French doors to central bay and decorative iron balustrade, above which is a decorative typanum with an oval window. Open loggia with Ionic columns to third floor; flanking pilasters have cartouches to tops; pediment over. Plain frieze; parapet bears theatre name in red faience lettering. Stair windows to either side of niche on 3 levels comprise keyed oculi to ground floor, and paired square-headed windows to mezzanine and first floor. Oval windows to third floor with cherub-head keystones and swags, flanked by niched Ionic columns. Rich modillion cornice. Parapet bearing 2 over-life-size female figures, and urns to each corner. Crowning octagonal Ionic cupola in manner of Wren, bearing gilded figure of Anna Pavlova (replicated from original taken down in 1940 and lost). To right (E) is a single-storey triple-arched entrance with a balustraded parapet bearing the theatre name, formerly leading to a queuing yard for the gallery, now the entrance to the 2000 foyer extension. Symmetrical side (W) elevation of 4 storeys and 9 bays arranged 1-2-3-2-1; outer single bays slightly recessed, inner ones are divided into 3 main bays (2-3-2) by rusticated pilasters. Chanelled rusticated ground floor with central entrance and vehicle entrances to outer bays. Above, central 3 bays are recessed and faced in stone with giant order of coupled Ionic columns in antis. Paired casement windows. Modillion cornice. The pub to the left of the theatre is the Duke of York.
photo.tags: london greaterlondon england unitedkingdom greatbritain victoria westminster cityofwestminster theatre victoriapalace victoriapalacetheatre billyelliot musical gradeiilisted gradeiilistedbuilding alfredbutt frankmatcham henrylovattltd penteliko keramo gibbscanning pub publichouse dukeofyork dukeofyorkvictoria victoriast
photo.title: Billy Elliot - Victoria Palace - Victoria, London

photo.description: Duke of York Square, Chelsea. Formerly known as Duke of York's Headquarters and before that, the Royal Military Asylum, it was designed by John Sanders (who also did the Sandringham military academy) and completed in 1801. The Saatchi Gallery moved here in 2008.

photo.title: Admiralty Arch

photo.description: According to Walter H Godfrey, in this Survey of London (1913), Argyll House owes its name to John, the fourth Duke of Argyll who lived here for the last two years of his life, from 1769-70. It was built, however, for John Perrin (aka Pierene) in 1723 by the Venetian architect Giacomo Leoni. Perrin's name appears on the rate books for the house from 1724 to 1740 and his monogramed initials have been wrought into the iron gates. Leoni described Argyll House in the following terms: "Upon the King's Road between Chelsea and London this little House of my Invention was built for Mr. John Pierene. The Kitchen, Buttery and other offices are within the Basement. The Apartments are of a size, suitable to a private Family. The Door in Front is Doric, with two columns and two half Pilasters. The ornaments of the Windows are all of Stone, as is also the great Cornice; the rest is gray Brick, which in my opinion sorting extremely well with white Stone, makes a beautiful Harmony of Colours. At the further End of the Garden behind the House, into which you descend from a small Terrass, are the Stables and Coach-houses, with Lodgings for Servants. The Front towards the Road has a Courtyard, enclosed with an Iron Palisade" (From: 'Argyll House, No. 211, King's Road', Survey of London: volume 4: Chelsea, pt II (1913), pp. 82-85. URL: www.british-history.ac.uk/report.aspx?compid=74648 Date accessed: 07 June 2009). The King's Road is so called because from the late 17th century it formed a private royal route between Whitehall and Hampton Court. Charles II was a regular user, taking the King's Road from Westminster to Fulham Palace, from where he would take a boat to Hampton Court. The road itself is however much older, dating back to 704 and being the original route taken by the Bishops of London to their summer residence of Fulham Palace. By 1711, the use of the road was controlled by six gates, including those at Chelsea College, Church Street, World's End and Sands End (where Nell Gywn, Charles II's mistress is thought to have had a house, Sandford Manor). In 1719 the use of the road was opened up to those with privilege tokens: by 1722 these tokens are known to have been made of copper and four types baring the stamp "the King's Private Road' have been found - examples of which have been sunk into the road in Duke of York Square. By the 1780s the road was much more generally used but it was not until responsibility for the road passed from the monarch to the parish in 1820 that it became a public thoroughfare. It was considerably widened in the 1860s.
photo.tags: london june2009 chelsea
photo.title: Entrance, Argyll House

photo.title: Nameplate, Argyll House

photo.description: This picture is part of a set, and to get the full meaning you need to work through the pictures in order, reading the underlying text each time. Of course, life doesn't always have meaning, so really you can do whatever you want. After all, "why be so serious", right? Step 2: "Up the stairs prepare for battle. You'll be greeted with open arms. On the island, discover those who died in war and divide by the women who surround them." Having counted the columns, we are ready to head off. This clue tells us where to go, and what we'll see when we get there. So we cross the road, go up the stairs, past the Duke of York column - until we see this statue. It's pitch dark, but the "open arms" that we can make out suggest that we are at the right place. We can't read the death-toll off the statue (I took this picture at ISO800 - it really was dark!), but Stuart does his research and lets us know over the phone. We count a few female figures, do some long division ... and get 90. And now?
photo.tags: uk london 2008 batman joker whysoserious darkknight movie adventure hunt secret puzzle midnight
photo.title: Clue 2

photo.description: All six photos uploaded today were taken in the new Saatchi Gallery - new at least for me, since this was the first time I have been to there, at the recent venue, at former Duke of Yorks Headquarters (originally a military school, then a military barrack, but completely transformed and refurbished for Saatchi in 2004-2008, though all older outlook remained), close to Sloane Square. The exhibition was "Unveiled: New Art from the Middle East" - all art object photos are credited to the artists.
photo.tags: london saatchi saatchigallery column columns
photo.title: A Saatchi Day

It was built, however, for John Perrin (aka Pierene) in 1723 by the Venetian architect Giacomo Leoni. Perrin's name appears on the rate books for the house from 1724 to 1740 and his monogramed initials have been wrought into the iron gates. Leoni described Argyll House in the following terms: "Upon the King's Road between Chelsea and London this little House of my Invention was built for Mr. John Pierene. The Kitchen, Buttery and other offices are within the Basement. The Apartments are of a size, suitable to a private Family. The Door in Front is Doric, with two columns and two half Pilasters. At the further End of the Garden behind the House, into which you descend from a small Terrass, are the Stables and Coach-houses, with Lodgings for Servants. The Front towards the Road has a Courtyard, enclosed with an Iron Palisade" (From: 'Argyll House, No. 211, King's Road', Survey of London: volume 4: Chelsea, pt II (1913), pp. 82-85. URL: www.british-history.ac.uk/report.aspx?compid=74648 Date accessed: 07 June 2009). photo.description: BIRTHDAY OUTING TO CHISWICK HOUSE (12/21) Brian on The Classic Bridge in the grounds of Chiswick Park, London. The Classic Bridge "which replaced a wooden bridge ... was built for the 5th Duke of Devonshire in 1774 and its design is attributed to James Wyatt." The grounds and lake were all part of the "revolutionary" landscaping here at what was "the birthplace of the English Landscape Movement and the inspiration for great gardens from Blenheim Palace to New Yorkâ€™s Central Park. Originally created by Lord Burlington [1694-1753] and William Kent [1685-1748] in 1729, the garden was inspired by the sights of the Grand Tour and romance of classical Italian landscape painting; it was conceived as a single, living artwork. Burlington and Kent replaced the formality of the existing renaissance garden with a freer, more luscious design. Straight lines were out, curves and clusters in. â€˜Naturalâ€™ spaces were created, their informality highlighted by the careful addition of sculpture and other architectural details including an Ionic temple and Doric column." (Quoted text from: www.chgt.org.uk/index.asp?Pageid=12) See also: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chiswick_House en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_Boyle,_3rd_Earl_of_Burlington en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Kent The bridge appears to have been built in Portland Stone. Photo taken by Jill ID: DSC_3228 - Version 2
photo.tags: greatbritain england london chiswick chiswickhouse 18thcentury lordburlington richardboyle 3rdearlofburlington thearchitectearl goose lake georgian water artificiallake artificialriver tree plant williamkent landscapearchitect landscapegarden scenery englishlandscapemovement bridge theclassicbridge jameswyatt portlandstone people ourfamiy darkroomdaze brian animal dog londonboroughofhounslow
photo.title: No, that's not my dog

photo.description: BIRTHDAY OUTING TO CHISWICK HOUSE (11/21) The Classic Bridge over the artificial lake (or 'river') in the grounds of Chiswick House, London, viewed from the W. The Classic Bridge "which replaced a wooden bridge ... was built for the 5th Duke of Devonshire in 1774 and its design is attributed to James Wyatt." The grounds and lake were all part of the "revolutionary" landscaping here at what was "the birthplace of the English Landscape Movement and the inspiration for great gardens from Blenheim Palace to New Yorkâ€™s Central Park. Originally created by Lord Burlington [1694-1753] and William Kent [1685-1748] in 1729, the garden was inspired by the sights of the Grand Tour and romance of classical Italian landscape painting; it was conceived as a single, living artwork. Burlington and Kent replaced the formality of the existing renaissance garden with a freer, more luscious design. Straight lines were out, curves and clusters in. â€˜Naturalâ€™ spaces were created, their informality highlighted by the careful addition of sculpture and other architectural details including an Ionic temple and Doric column." (Quoted text from: www.chgt.org.uk/index.asp?Pageid=12) See also: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chiswick_House en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_Boyle,_3rd_Earl_of_Burlington en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Kent The bridge appears to have been built in Portland Stone. The little girl (far R) in Flickr colours is a coincidence. ID: DSC_3226 - Version 2

photo.title: Classical bridge

photo.description: "The west side of the base of the Monument displays an emblematical sculpture, by Caius Gabriel Cibber, in alto and bas relief, of the destruction of the City; with King Charles II, and his brother, James, the Duke of York (later James II) surrounded by Liberty, Architecture, and Science, giving directions for its restoration." (Best viewed Large) This 202 foot tall statue was built by Sir Christopher Wren and Robert Hooke, to commemorate the Great Fire of London (1666). When completed in 1677 it was the tallest free standing column in the world. A 311 step winding staircase (accessible to the public) leads to an observation deck. The monument has been dwarfed by development in London's Financial district where it is located. Here is some more information on "The Monument". en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monument_to_the_Great_Fire_of_London
photo.tags: london england spring 2006 themonument greatfireoflondon christopherwren greatbritain unitedkingdom
photo.title: The Monument Base - Sculpture - Christopher Wren

photo.description: Frederick Augustus, second son of George III, commander in chief of the Army and The Grand old Duke of York in the famous nursery rhyme, stands on top of a Tuscan column made of Aberdeenshire granite 124 feet high. At the time of building in 1831-34 a popular joke was that he stood so high so as to be out of reach of his creditors; when he died in1827 he was Â£2 million in debt. The whole structure including the 53 square feet of concrete foundations cost Â£25,000 , most of which was raised by stopping the pay of every officer and soldier in the Army for one day. The column was designed by Sir Benjamin Wyatt and the bronze 14 feet statue was sculpted by Sir Richard Westmacott. The column was opened to the public but almost immediately it became a popular venue for suicides. The railings surrounding the square balcony were raised but the suicides found a way and the column was closed to the public in the 1850s. I heard a story that a PC from AD had climbed the spiral staircase to the top in company with a maintenance crew and reported that the staircase was covered with the droppings from generations of pigeons. The building on the right with the awning in Carlton House Terrace is The German Embassy after having been Prussia House since it was built.
photo.tags: carltonhouseterrace waterlooplace dukeofyorkcolumn nelsonscolumn germanembassy pedestrians canonrow metropolitan london uk cannonrow
photo.title: Carlton House Terrace

photo.tags: london themall statue column carltonhouseterrace frederickdukeofyork
photo.title: Typical male

photo.description: The Duke of York Column is a monument in London, England, to Prince Frederick, Duke of York, the second eldest son of King George III. It is located near where Regent Street meets The Mall, in between the two terraces of Carlton House Terrace. The column was chiseled from pink granite, and the statue created by Sir Richard Westmacott in 1834. The statue is facing northwest, towards the Crimean War Memorial and Piccadilly Circus. The height of the column is 123' 6", or 37.6m).
photo.tags: london england greatbritian britain dukeofyork memorial
photo.title: Duke of York Column

photo.description: Taken from Duke of York's Column, Waterloo Place and the end of Regent Street are embraced as well as the famous double-decker red buses.
photo.title: Waterloo Place

photo.description: Me with the designer of the lift from architects Matthew Lloyd. It works roughly like this: Falling water tanks on either side of the lift raise it (or vice-versa lower it). with solar panels powering the pumps - hence a zero energy product (well, zero fossil fuel energy). The test flight worked so well with me I didn't realise it was happening. It's a lovely idea. It is being showcased here on the steps beneath the Duke of York's column leading down to the Mall as part of the London Festival of Architects www.lfa2010.org/. This one is designed for disabled people and they hope it will be adopted at this spot for the Olympics. But it could work with any kind of lift - including skyscrapers I was assured..
photo.title: Me testing a zero energy lift on the Mall
